item.title: Germany Bans Neo-Nazi Group as Far-Right Gains From Migration Crisis
item.description: The move against White Wolves Terrorcrew is intended to demonstrate that the authorities will not tolerate agitation against foreigners and migrants.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: French Student Who ‘Took Some Breaks’ Earns Doctorate at 90
item.description: Colette Bourlier became one of the oldest people in France to be awarded the degree, 30 years after she first began researching immigrant workers.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Colette Bourlier defended her thesis at the Université de Franche-Comté in Besançon, France, on Tuesday.

item.title: Denmark Again Tops the World Happiness Report
item.description: At the bottom of the list of more than 150 countries was Burundi, a poor African nation where a violent political crisis broke out last year.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: A market in Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi. Burundi, a poor African nation where a violent political crisis broke out last year, came in last according to the fourth World Happiness Report.

item.title: Belgium Says Algerian Killed in Raid May Have Had Links to Radical Islam
item.description: Mohamed Belkaid, a 35-year-old who was in Belgium illegally, tried to open fire on officers and was shot and killed by a special forces sniper.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: The building in Brussels where a man was killed during a counterterrorism raid on Tuesday. Police officers found a flag of the Islamic State, a book on the Salafist school of Islam and a Kalashnikov rifle during the operation.

item.title: Editorial: Reconsider a Refugee Deal With Turkey
item.description: Any agreement between Europe and President Erdogan must respect international law and the values of the E.U.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Pakistan’s Supreme Court Lifts Travel Ban on Pervez Musharraf
item.description: Mr. Musharraf, a former military leader facing charges of treason, has been in poor health, and the ruling would let him seek treatment abroad.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Pervez Musharraf, a former military ruler of Pakistan, at his farmhouse in Islamabad, the capital, in 2013.

item.title: Sinosphere: Unofficial Poll on Legislative Proposals Hints at Chinese Priorities
item.description: Most of the popular proposals voted on in an unscientific Internet poll focused on narrowly defined social issues, skirting broader questions of governance.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW and SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Vendors waiting for people to buy dogs in a market in Yulin, a city in southern China that holds an annual dog meat festival. A proposal to ban the eating of dog and cat meat received the most votes in an online poll.

item.title: Sinosphere: Delegates Endorse China’s 5-Year Plan but Resist Saying Much Else
item.description: Delegates overwhelmingly approved President Xi Jinping’s framework for China’s development, but they and their staff shied away from casual conversation.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Delegates arriving for the final meeting of the National People’s Congress at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: 2 Female Suicide Bombers Attack Nigerian Mosque, Killing Over 20
item.description: The militant Islamic group Boko Haram is suspected of carrying out the bombings, which wounded 18 people, an army spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: China Seeks to Avoid Mass Layoffs While Cutting Production
item.description: Remarks by Premier Li Keqiang on Wednesday reflected the difficult — some say unsustainable — policy combination that China’s leaders hope to achieve.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Pakistan Bus Bombing Kills at Least 14 in Peshawar
item.description: The bus was carrying government workers to the provincial capital when it exploded. The police said the bomb was concealed in baggage left aboard.
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN
item.media:description: A man injured in a bomb blast on Wednesday aboard a bus carrying government workers was taken to a hospital in Peshawar, Pakistan.

item.title: Florence Journal: Florence Tackles Duomo Defacement With a New Tool: Virtual Graffiti
item.description: After scrubbing tower walls of “we were here” markups, officials create a digital space for all those symbols, signatures and notes to posterity.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The dome of the Santa Maria del Fiore cathedral, better known as the Duomo, and Giotto’s bell tower, the Campanile, in Florence, Italy.

item.title: North Korea Sentences Otto Warmbier, U.S. Student, to 15 Years’ Labor
item.description: Mr. Warmbier, an undergraduate at the University of Virginia who tried to steal a propaganda poster, was convicted of subversion, news services said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Troubleshooter Meets North Korea Diplomats on Detained American
item.description: At the meeting, former Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico urged the North to release Otto F. Warmbier of Cincinnati, a college student.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: With Sri Srinivasan, Indian Town Prays for a ‘Son’ on Supreme Court
item.description: Sri Srinivasan is known in Washington as a brilliant judge and possible Supreme Court nominee. In his family’s village in India, he is known as “our son.”
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Serena De Sanctis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The village of Mela Thiruvenkatanathapuram, in Tamil Nadu state. The village was home to the family of Sri Srinivasan.

item.title: News Analysis: What Quagmire? Even in Withdrawal, Russia Stays a Step Ahead
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin’s move to withdraw the bulk of his forces from Syria caught the White House by surprise.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama, on Tuesday in the Oval Office, had long argued that Russia’s military invention in Syria would backfire.

item.title: Women Who Brought Zika Fears Home With Them
item.description: U.S. women who traveled to Central and South American countries and are pregnant deal with the worry of a virus that is linked to birth defects.
item.dc:creator: LAURA BEIL
item.media:credit: Bryan Meltz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roxanne Forest came home from Costa Rica with insect bites in her second trimester of pregnancy. On her latest ultrasound, the fetus seemed normal.

item.title: Ex-President ‘Lula’ Could Avoid Prison by Joining Brazilian Cabinet
item.description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, facing possible arrest in a graft inquiry, is reported to be a candidate for a post that would legally protect him.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff with her predecessor, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, greeted supporters gathering outside his house this month in Sao Bernardo do Campo, near São Paulo, Brazil.

item.title: Editorial: The Opening to Cuba Widens
item.description: Ahead of President Obama’s trip to Cuba, the embargo has been eased to make travel between the two countries easier for Cubans and Americans.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: A Canadian Province’s Rocky Symbol Collapses Into Rubble
item.description: The tides that helped carve Elephant Rock, a natural stone formation in New Brunswick, Canada, out of the shoreline also played a role in its destruction.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: About half of Elephant Rock, a natural stone formation in New Brunswick, Canada, crumbled on Monday. The tides that helped carve it out of the shoreline also played a role in its destruction.
